pullRequest.body:
Prove `sum_eq_iSup`, an infinite sum is equal to the supremum of summands.

---

### PR summary [48b252a54e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16910/commits/48b252a54e2006ba0ad143f0da46fe9c55397d1a)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ sum_eq_iSup`
`+ sum_eq_iSup_lift`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>
```

ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
bors merge
This PR was included in a batch that was canceled, it will be automatically retried

Thanks! ðŸš€

maintainer merge

Thanks! ðŸš€

maintainer merge
Isn't the `Î¹` variable declared at the start of the file?
As much as I enjoy golfing, I think two substs might be a bit too much. It's a bit hard to understand how this proof is operating. Can you rewrite this as a short tactic-mode proof instead?
Is it more direct to prove this first and use `lift_id` for the other result?
Small golf, can you use `apply (iSup_le_sum f).antisymm'` instead?
Can you make the universe exxplicit on this cardinal?
Based on the surrounding lemmas, I think this should use `ciSup` in the name?
As I understand it (or rather, as @YaelDillies told me), the convention is to use `iSup` rather than `ciSup` for concrete types. If that's so, then really the surrounding lemmas should be renamed.
Or is the rule about where a `BddAbove` assumption is needed?
The rule as I have understood it is that the `c` is used as disambiguation, and dropped when there is no ambiguity. Here there can't be an honest to god iSup, so ciSup means iSup
I tend to agree it's a pretty weird rule

```suggestion
  sum_eq_iSup_lift hÎ¹ (lift_id #Î¹ â–¸ h)
```
`â–¸` automatically uses hypothesese the right way around
Ah darn it! I thought this was one of my PRs again. Sorry for that.

> `â–¸` automatically uses hypothesese the right way around

It doesn't seem to in this case. It works when `(lift_id #Î¹) â–¸ h` is a seperate `have` but not as part of the entire expression.
Hmm maybe a universe unification issue

pullRequest.title: feat(SetTheory/Cardinal/Ordinal): sum_eq_iSup
